bibl.title: Despatch from Ezekiel E. Smith to George L. Rives
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.ab:
Consulate General, U. S. A.
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 18th 1889.

Mr. Ezekiel E. Smith
To the Department of State.
div1.p: The Consular Agent at Elmina, Gold Coast Colony, wishes forms: 101, 103, 117, 120, 130, also, an American flag, or flag of the U.S.
div1.ab:
Consulate General, U. S. A.
Monrovia, Liberia, Feb'y 18th 1889

Honorable G. L. Rives
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D. C.
div1.p: I have the honor respectfully to forward, herewith, a communication from the U.S. Consular Agent at Elmina, Gold Coast Colony, requesting supplies for his office.
I have them not on hand, in this Consulate General.

I am, sir,
Your obedient servant,
Ezekiel E. Smith,
U.S. Consul Gen'l.

Consulate of the United States,
Elmina, Gold Coast Colony
December 10th 1888.

Ezekiel E. Smith Esqre:
U.S. Minister Resident & Consul General
Monrovia, Liberia
Your despatch no. 1 to hand in reply I have the honor to state, that I am most in need for this Consulate the following Forms: No. 101 (the new form) & Nos: 103; 117; 120. 130.
I would feel much obliged if your Honor could supply me with the above; I should thank you also if you could supply this Consulate with an American Flag, which is very much needed.

I am, Sir,
Your most obedient Servant
G. E. Eminsang
U.S. Consular Agent
